Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton.

Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: Protests aren't necessarily hate. That's just bizarre. Protesting is a constitutional right (you know, that first amendment?). And protesting is not the same thing as destroying property. Sure, people have a right to their feelings - but you have to admit that there's a problem when somebody's hate revolves around efforts to deny equal standing to others whom he/she sees as fundamentally lesser, such as neo-Nazis or white supremacists. Personally, I don't think such hate should be criminalized, but it absolutely should be excoriated, loud and clear. Because that's not the America I want to live in. 

Finally, though violence is always wrong, in terms of message there is no comparison between antifa and white supremacists. Anita is against fascism - ethnic cleansing, blood and soil, etc. White supremacists and neo-Nazis are by definition hateful and exclusionary. They're not even remotely comparable.

Comment: Of course businesses will try to pass the cost off to consumers. That's understood. But since the tax applies only to large companies, and since many of them have national pricing strategies, they can go only so far with this without creating worse difficulties for themselves. Oregon is small potatoes. The strategy here is an excellent one. Even if the corporations managed to pass on 2/3 of the tax, we would still be getting 3 billion dollars in additional revenue for a consumption tax of 2 billion. I'll take that. The structure of this tax is rational and productive. An important question is whether we are going to go on tolerating the erratic and wasteful tax structure we have now, where programs and departments ands agencies are slashed and then re-funded in ways that are wasteful and inefficient and lead to poor performance because revenues are so irregular. It's wasteful and stupid. We need stability. This is the best proposal for stability that I've seen in my 30 years here.

Comment: Quote from the article:  Among the misconceptions about Pidgin, said Darrell H.Y. Lum, a panel speaker and the co-founder of Bamboo Ridge Press, is that it is “broken English” or a “language of the stupid.”  I've lived in Hawaii for 60 years, grew up in Hilo, learned pidgin for casual conversation among local friends, am part-Hawaiian, dropped my Southern drawl, and became an English teacher and librarian.  In all those years, I have never heard anyone describe pidgin as broken or for the stupid.  I've known people who were fascinated and intrigued by it but never considered it broken or the people who spoke it stupid.  Using pidgin to communicate in certain circumstances and contexts is one thing.  Yes, there IS a time and place for it.  Teaching students to speak it in public schools?  When hell freezes over and pigs fly.  Fix the current problems with public schools before creating another one.

Comment: Excellent column, Professor Haycox. Many Alaskans may be unaware we had our own direct brush with McCarthyism in 1950 when Andrew Schoeppel, a middling senator from Kansas of no distinction, accused Ernest Gruening and the Alaska statehood movement of Communist sympathies because they had once hired a lobbyist with ties to the Eastern Bloc. The baseless charge eventually ensnared Oscar Chapman, Interior secretary under President Truman, who Schoeppel accused of lying in his oath of office. Gruening and Chapman survived because they occupied positions of power, but, as Haycox notes, many others were not so lucky. Consider the reputations and lives that stand to be destroyed by Trump's self-pitying and imbecilic rantings.

Comment: This news story has generated more letters, comments, articles, etc. than any other that I can remember in my 40 years in Eugene. Most have been thoughtful, honest, insightful, and have given me a lot to think about - particularly in regards to my own biases, both the ones I know and those I don't even know that I have. No matter how much I read, talk, watch, experience, empathize with, etc, I will never know what it is like to be Black, a Woman, a Jew, Gay, etc. I will never be able to fully know what it is like to be anyone else other than myself, and no one else will ever know what it is like to be me.  
I doubt we'll ever be able to fully and collectively bridge the racial divides and prejudices in this country. We don't seem to be able to learn from our collective past without being labeled by it and stuck in it. Since I can't change it, I say live in the present and treat yourself and fellow human with as much dignity, integrity, understanding, civility, etc. as you can muster.

Comment: As an American, all  I can say is that this article is utter bull-shit.  Americans don't view medical care ars some sort of status symbol.  We are actually very realistic about what we have.  When our healthcare is good, it's very, very, good, and those of us that have it really don't want to lose it.  Those of us that have been stuck in the great Middle Class slide are fearful of losing it.  Those of us at the bottom of the list aspire to get it.  The problem is that asking people to give up some of it.. to ration our healthcare the way that many countries (like Canada) do, is simply antithetical to our founding meritocratic principals.  We all know that for everyone to have healthcare, we all have to give up some of it, but no one wants to be the pansy that goes first.  We are a people that like to grow the pie, not split it up in every finer or more proportionate pieces.  This cognitive dissonance is the source of our debate, and idiotic foreigners should just stay out of it.

Comment: Canaries in the coal mine? The cold water upwellings that bring the deep water nutrients closer to the surface where the krill feed on them which in turn support these birds and our fisheries could be breaking down from the warmer waters in the North Pacific. Think of it as a conveyor belt moving cold nutrient rich water to the surface where it can be utilized by the small crustaceans and copepods that herring and these birds feed on. What people don't realize is this system is the foundation of the entire food chain in this ecosystem. It breaks down and everything that depends on it, including us suffer. I can't believe some of the stupid and ignorant comments on here and I dearly pray they do no reflect  people's intellect and politics. How depressing.

Comment: I have just read the abstract of De Kock et al, they recommend exactly what I do. Comment: In 1957 I was born and living in New York State and being raised in a small town as a strict Catholic. At my first communion I received a Girl Scout doll dressed in a Brownie uniform from my Aunt and sponsor at my communion. I lived to be a girl scout from then on and could not wait to join and participate and get my uniform, earn badges and march in the local parades on holidays. The meetings were held in the basement of a non- catholic church. No religion was involved. One day my mom told me that I was sinning and I had to stop the troop or I would be excommunicated at the age of 8 and go to hell. This was according to the Catholic Church. I never got over the unfairness of the Catholic Church bullying me as a small child. I quit the church when I turned 18 and so did all of the teens in my extensive family who were Catholic. This was common in the 1960's and continues as the Catholic Church continues to be more outdated in each passing year. The Catholic Church is the real loser.

Comment: "His research shows that the inventory of homes for sale is tighter in periods of rising rates than in periods of falling rates. That’s because borrowers with a low-rate loan are less inclined to purchase a new home with more expensive debt if they don’t have to."

True, until the homeowner dies, gets divorced, or HAS to move for a job. Then the house WILL be sold, and it won't sell at a peak price to a buyer limited by the monthly payment, as the payment will be higher with higher mtg rates. Unless the seller can find a richer buyer, they will lower the price if they want to sell.

The same thing that happened in 2006 is repeating. Prices are increasingly unreachable by someone making the median salary, and those that are buying must stretch more to close. Eventually there are no more than can do it. Introduce a recession and prices will gradually fall further as people lose jobs and then run out of savings or need to move. Incomes are fundamentally out of line with prices.

Comment: I would like to see the state continue to work on eliminating non-compete contracts. 

The last bill covered engineers and programmers for High-Tech companies. 

I would like to see this extended to all companies covering all engineers and programming and IT personnel. 

We need to free up workers to work at these hi tech companies if we want to diversify our economy. 

IIRC many of the big businesses in town like the hotel industry was opposed to non-compete contracts being eliminated when the first bill was proposed. So many of their managers and supervisors are prevented from working elsewhere because of these contracts. The labor unions don't care because these guys are considered management. But the Democratic party should take up the slack. It should be placed on its platform which may encounter Union opposition.

Kudos to senator Glenn Wakai in narrowing the scope of the bill to have gotten it passed in the next session.

Comment: Some background would be helpful.  First, there have been different claims over the years about big oil discoveries up North, and nothing came of them.  The shale oil find touted by Great Bear is stalled.  Anadarko announced an elephant field 17 years ago just North of the Brooks Range- nothing.  

One reason big finds are left in the ground is the global corporations do not want the oil developed- increased supply drives down prices- and profits.  Exxon refused to develop Pt. Thomson.  Alaska had to sue to get Exxon to honor its lease terms- and then Sullivan gave away Pt. Thomson.  Massive rip-off that has cost Alaska billions.  Of course Sullivan got rewarded for his sell out of Alaskans.

It is worth mentioning that ACES brought forward these kinds of developments- with the rich exploration credits.  This work began in 2008- under ACES.

Under SB-21, this find- if ever developed, could break Alaska.  We'd pay $8 dollars per barrel for "new" oil- cost us $8 to $16 million per day.

Comment: Provide to whomever you wish to believe the claim.  That's entirely up to you.  Putting forth a claim about some personal illness without providing valid documented evidence to support that claim, is meaningless.  I couldn't care less whether he provides it or not.  I'm simply exposing the fallacy of such a claim.

You are assuming that an online commenter is being accurate and truthful when he claims to have  skeletal fluorosis.  In the absence of valid, documented medical evidence that he does have skeletal fluorosis, there is no need to go any further.  Whether he wishes to provide that evidence or not is entirely his choice.  Unless he does, however, there is no credibility to his claim. 

That you don't understand these basic principles of scientific evidence is typical of fluoridation opponents.  Until they do begin to understand what constitutes valid facts and evidence, they will remain frustrated with their lack of credibility.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: "The exception is parents who want to deny their children life-saving procedures, usually on religious or cultural grounds. They should be overruled."

You can't grant courts authority in those cases but deny it in cases where the shoe is on the other foot. Either they get involved in medical decisions or they don't; you can't choose cases to get the decisions you want. Since there are many situations where we can all agree that a court must step in to protect a patient, we are stuck with courts being, potentially, involved in all kinds of medical decisions. In this particular case, Great Ormond Street (one of the best paediatric hospitals in the world) must feel very strongly that there is a clear case of excess suffering being imposed on a hopeless case for them to take the unusual step of asking to override the parents' wishes. It seems very unlikely that any treatment can 'bypass mitochondrial function' and any benefit is still likely to leave the child vegetative on a ventilator.

Sigh......more conspiracy nonsense from ‘fluoridealert” the biased little website of the New York antifluoridationist faction, “FAN”.  One would think that the browsers on antifluoridationist computers would access more sites than just that one.......but apparently not.

Fluorosilic acid does not exist in fluoridated water at the tap.  It is therefore not ingested.  Once it releases its fluoride ions into water, FSA no longer exists in that water.  It is gone before the water leaves the treatment plant.  FSA is obviously of no concern, whatsoever.  

The only substances ingested as a result of fluoridation with FSA are fluoride ions, identical to those which have always existed in water, and trace contaminants in barely detectable trace amounts far below EPA mandated maximum allowable levels of safety.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: I hear your point, A_R. There's some information that says incarceration works. Some says it doesn't. I believe where it doesn't work is because conditions in jail practically pamper offenders. It's become a country club in some places. Jail used to be a BAD place to end up. I think some of the so-called 'reforms' need to be rolled back. Making it an unpleasant place to be can be done without being so-called 'inhumane'. Make it a REAL deterrent again and I am willing to bet things will improve. And, believe it or not, I believe that -assistance to reform- needs to be a part of it. Unless you are willing to bury someone in jail for life, they are eventually going to get out. They have to have a reason to change. So with punishment, there needs to be hope. Give them the chance, but they have to reach for it THEMSELVES. Just like any junkie, unless a person WANTS to change, you can't make them. If they don't... well, being 60 years old on release makes it harder to commit crimes...

I remember walking with a friend on the U of O campus when we came upon a man writhing on a bench by the sidewalk.  He was clearly suffering from Parkinson's disease.  "Can you help me?," he asked.  We came to find out that he had been walking, sat down to rest and then could not get back up to his feet.  He had been asking passersby for help for over three hours.  No one would, because they were probably afraid of this old, desheveld man with scary-looking, uncontroled movements.  He had wet himself becasue no one was willing to "get involved."  We helped him up and gave him a ride home.

People do lose their lives "getting involved."  But blessings to those who transcend their fear and take action.  It works for the common good.... most of the time.

Comment: Focusing on prevention with first time offenders is fine.  But watering down what constitutes an offense is another thing.  We're seeing an epidemic of home invasions and burglaries that are committed by the same people over and over again.  But the thresholds have increased and the criminals know what they are.  So if they rip you off but stay just below those thresholds, they get a misdemeanor slap on the wrist and are released to do it again.  

There needs to be mandatory sentencing for people caught repeating the same types of crimes.  Anyone caught doing these types of crimes while addicted to opioids and meth need to do confinement with intensive treatment (whatever that means).  At least the addicts will know that they face a week of withdrawal if they get busted.  

treatment's expensive.  Almost every town in Alaska is feeling the opioids epidemic.  So implement a temporary 5-year 'treatment tax' to fund programs.  After 5 years we reevaluate whether it's been effective.

Comment: Wasn't one simple activator for the riots. It was a combination of many factors that were brewing for months within the dem. ranks and anti-war population leading up to the convention. Certain Repubs. might like to think otherwise. 

I will say in hindsight, the Chicago Eight, the Youth International Party (YIPPIES), Students for a Democratic Society and the National Mobilization Committee to end the War in Vietnam would have been better served in the long run, had they disrupted the RNC convention in Miami that year as they did with the Dems. in Chicago. Sadly, thousands more young men and Vietnamese ended up dying between 1969 and 1974 under a Republican administration that was hellbent on pursuing the “Peace with Honor” con.

Comment: Thanks to each of you for your thoughtful and detailed responses. 

I may sound old school, but after more than 15 years of directly or indirectly managing sizable online communities, I have found commenters using their real names to be more honest, factual and interested in civil exchanges. Yes, there are many exceptions -- this thread and most on this site among them -- and there continue to be good arguments for and against. The fact is that after years of hard lessons, I remain biased toward real names. 

But in the interest of being open-minded in a new community and widening the funnel for quality feedback (and through an impressive platform like Civil Comments), here's what I'll do: I'll amend my initial concept and accept anonymous submissions and value their merits just as I would those using real names. I pledge to be open-minded and judge those just as evenly.  We'll see how that works and adjust if needed.

Comment: CLDC to Host Know Your Rights information booth at Kesey Square

Date & Time: Thursday, August 18th 7:30pm-9:00pm

Where: Kesey Square (10th & Broadway)

The Civil Liberties Defense Center will be hosting a Know Your Rights information booth at Kesey Square to empower everyone in the Eugene community to know their rights when interacting with the police. Advice on constitutional rights, such as the right to assemble in public places like Kesey Square, sidewalks and public parks will be emphasized as well as basic instruction on how to “Copwatch,” or video record law enforcement.

The increased presence of the Eugene Police Department has made many in the community feel less welcome and afraid to be downtown. The EPD has been observed hassling the unhoused during their “outreach” efforts downtown.

Comment: A couple things to remember about preferred shares.  First, every pref differs due to the terms specific to each issue. Yes, they are senior over common stock, but in the event of bankruptcy, don't expect to get much, if anything as there are still multiple layers of debt/creditors above you.  Also, keep in mind that as long as the dividend is paid, prefs have no voting rights. 

I am not saying prefs aren't a good investment, for many they fit well depending on risk profile and investing objectives. Just know what you are investing in before you purchase.

Comment: The only well established case where small pox infested blankets were distributed to native Americans  was during Pontiac's rebellion when they were besieging the British and American colonists at Fort Pitt (Pittsburgh). What effect that might have  had  on the more general small pox epidemic at the time affecting native Americans and settlers  at the time is moot. (You might want to read about Pontiac's rebellion. The brutality was rather two-way.)  There aren't, so far as I know, instances of the Hudson's Bay Company or the Northwest Company or their agents in Canada distributing small pox infested blankets. The reason is that fur trading companies depended on aboriginal suppliers for their furs and much else for survival. Killing off your suppliers would be a self-destructive way of doing business.  That isn't to say that small pox wasn't a scourge among Canadian aboriginals but its spread was through human contact.

Comment: This bill to the best of my understanding rearranges Medicaid payments for health care for many ....

It puts a cap on the amount of "state match" that the individual states may get regardless of rising costs for care of their recipients....it takes away the "entitlement status" for Medicaid that has always been the case...and will increasingly reduce health services to the elderly and the poor

This is a sneaky backdoor effort to "contain" health care costs at the terrible price of eliminating health care to the truly vulnerable.

The effort to "block grant" to the states federal Medicaid "match" (which has been "capped" is part of the nefarious plan. Block grants are notorious as a scam to pass a problem downward and reduce costs while nobly claiming subsidiarity....only fools believe it.

It's not just the 14 million immediate victims of this bill...it's the 10-plus million MORE folks who will suffer the loss of care in the next few years with the "block granting/cap.

Comment: When you and some business partners "homesteaded"(leased that oil field) from the state it came with clauses. And it's time for a new legislature to rewrite the clauses of SB21 like the "new oil" and outrageous subsidies.

Comment: Of course. But developing those resources required massive amounts of capital. And the only entities that had the capital and the technical capability of monetizing our then untapped resources were "Big Oil" companies. Thanks to their investment, and the wisdom of early state leaders, we have a PF and enjoy a full array of state services without having to pay much if anything into the system. Which all comes while we receive a nice dividend each year.

Point is, I don't understand all the anti-oil sentiment. Companies are largely self-interested and make decisions that are based on creating value for their shareholders sure, but I can't think of any industry that has the ability to create as much economic benefit for the public at large as oil. I would think we would want smart policies to keep that industry healthy as it bleeds over into helping all of us do better economically whatever our profession.

Any successful program needs to have wide bipartisan support as well as the support of the professional providers. 
So, what will it be?
High tech and immediate access? (But, with high cost)
High tech and low cost? (But, without immediate access)
Immediate access and low cost? (But, without high tech)
Pick! Choose! Decide!
Otherwise. provision of medical care will remain a quagmire.

Comment: I followed up individual who is a professional tax preparation specialist. She indicated that she is familiar with the APTC.  She reviewed the number of returns she submitted last year the APTC percentage was less than 1% (.007 %) of submitted returns.  Note:  APTC is not given to those on Medicare.  The APTC applies to those individuals that do not qualify for Medicaid and fall below the income level that would qualify them for a tax credit (which the APTC).  However interestingly we rely on prior year's income (2016) reported by the taxpayer to qualify for APTC of upcoming year (2017).  Upon filing for 2017, if taxpayer understated or simply had reported above the estimate, the credit is paid back when filing taxes.  Hence, the if we back out the Medicaid recipients (who were a large percentage of ACA enrollees) the 90% seems a bit askew.  We would appreciate the source of this number (90%) and it would be interesting to have it vetted by her research department.  Thank You.

Comment: Cursive evolved as a faster style of handwriting when more documentation was required for increased  business transactions between the Europeans and the Far East.  Not lifting the writing instrument for each letter allowed the hand "to run" over the page.  Cursive handwriting became the standard form of  handwriting, and the only method taught, for many centuries.  Printing (the previously called "lettering" from centuries ago), was re-introduced into school curriculum around a century ago.   It was then that teachers first learned if you cannot write in cursive, you also are unable to read cursive writing. At that time the theory was that teaching printing would make learning cursive easier in grades two or three.  This was the process in North America for many decades.  Then those who developed curriculum decided it was WHAT students wrote that mattered, not HOW they wrote.  So today we again have students who are unable to read and write in cursive.  Calligraphy is an art form.

Comment: From Robin Brena:

"Changes that would help

If we continue with this percentage of "net income" approach, then it will need to be substantially revised. Among the revisions we should consider are:


(1) Increase the base rate for the major legacy fields and for merely harvesting our resources rather than exploring for additional resource.

(2) Eliminate credits (taken as deductions and paid) for all but the most challenged fields.

(3) Eliminate loss carryforwards.

(4) Eliminate the "new oil" definition or reduce the scope of its application to only the most challenged fields (which would not include Point Thomson).

(5) Increase progressivity.

(6) Add the auditing and legal resources necessary to ensure revenue certainty for the state and producers and to minimize gaming.

(7) Increase transparency so we know the financial performance of the producers operating in Alaska.

These revisions should increase current revenues by almost $3 billion"

Comment: It depends on one's notion of an active manager versus a passive one, because, as far as I'm aware, there's no authoritative definition of the two terms. Buffet has said that most investors would be best served by buying a low-cost index fund. Consistent with his favourite holding period, such investors would retain that fund until they need the money for some other purpose. Such fund would be passive because it only buys and sells when the index components change. Given Berkshire's cash balance, however, it doesn't need to sell for this purpose nor to rebalance its portfolio. It is one of the most significant sellers of put options, which is definitely not passive. There's a bit of "do as I say, not as I do" about Buffet in this advice he gives to investors while not having Berkshire strictly follow this approach. Nevertheless, you have your notion of active and passive management and I have mine.

Comment: Well Rob, I guess it depends on what one's definition of success is. Since the road bonds first started, we've seen a collapse of the use of any means of transportation that isn't a personal automobile. Of course this measurably increases the wear and tear on our roads, which "justifies" more road bonds and away we go. Frankly, that looks like failure to me, but it does cause more city staff funding.

We're actually talking about a significant number of cars here. Our 43% decline in cycling coupled with declines of over 50% in riding the bus and about 30% in walking (data from the US Census American Community Survey) means that we have over 9000 more cars on the road every single day in Eugene than we would have had without this failure. That accounts for ALL of the increase in traffic since the start of the road bonds.

To add insult to injury, those few remaining non-carbound residents get to pay for these repair bonds even though they do no damage to the roads.

Comment: This is advice for carb addicts with impaired fuel partitioning and mild insulin resistance, which is what would drive the average in a sample of 20,000.

It's a fallacy that dietary glucose is required for sufficient blood glucose. The liver makes all the glucose required (from glycogen, free fatty acids or protein), without transient blood glucose shortfall from elevated insulin. The brain also uses ketones, lactate and glutamine for fuel. The US Navy seals and other elite performers have been moving to high fat, high saturated fat ketogenic diets to enhance mental performance. Ketogenic diets are therapeutic for epilepsy and other neurological conditions. In the brain, sugar use is demand-driven via insulin signalling, whereas ketone use is supply-driven. Glucose oxidation also produces a lot more free radicals than ketones. The brain prefers ketones.

Snacking between meals is a sign of insulin resistance, which worsens because insulin levels don't return to baseline between meals.

Comment: I suggest that the Lieutenant Governor consult with his budget department. Here is why. On average, between 2008 and 2016, state spending increased by 3.7% annually. Now, that was not a linear progression; 2010 and 2011 realized a reduction in state spending. Nevertheless, to claim that the governor's proposed budget is down to the level of 2008 is nonsense. It is also helpful to look at the spending of other Pacific Northwest states on a per capita basis: Washington spends $5,250, Oregon spends $8,288 and yet Alaska spends $18,643.  Meanwhile Lieutenant Governor claims we don’t have a bloated budget. The numbers clearly say otherwise. Alaska state government spends far too much money.  In his essay the Lieutenant Governor said, “We have worked hard to reduce inefficiency in government.”  Really? Again, the numbers say otherwise. The Lieutenant Governor is making the case that every state program is essential while proposing new ones. That is a politician's justification for new taxes.

Comment: Before globalization, advances in technology and other disrupting factors corporate concentration was greater than it is now yet the wealth gap was not growing; workers could look forward to a modest but steady growth living standards and did not fear for their children's future,

With the advent of global supply chains this model was broken; companies now have to maximize profit to satisfy investors and to provide products and services at the lowest possible price for consumers in order to remain competitive.  This led to the growth in lobbying funded by corporations and the wealthy to influence legislation favourable to their goals.

Government has the responsibility ensure that corporations act for the common good and should strive to do so through sensible regulation that encourages distribution of wealth more equitably and ensures that ethical standards are maintained.  Most governments are failing to do so to the detriment of democracy.

Comment: It has  never been done.

Trump is now in office and could be considered a lame duck since his terms does end in 2020.  Should we wait to see if he is reelected before he nominates a person for SCOTUS?

...  nearly all Presidents so far have been able to appoint at least one Justice. The four exceptions are William Henry Harrison, Zachary Taylor, Andrew Johnson, and Jimmy Carter. Harrison died a month after taking office, though his successor (John Tyler) made an appointment during that presidential term. Taylor likewise died early in his presidential term, although his successor (Millard Fillmore) also made a Supreme Court nomination before the end of that term. Johnson was denied the opportunity to appoint a Justice by a contraction in the size of the Supreme Court, which Congress may dictate. Jimmy Carter is the only President who completed at least one full term in office without making a nomination to the Court during his presidency.

Comment: If that's your idea of a serious question, then you're not a very serious person. It's a multi-polar world, and while I don't like to call any country "super," it's obvious that Russia is one of the top-tier powers.
Why did you bring up GDP? You must have had a thought to support why you think that's a relevant measurement, here.
It's worth noting that Russia's average monthly income is about 1/8th, or maybe 1/10th what it is in Canada, and that cost in Russia for labour and goods, including military goods, is vastly cheaper than in the West. Russia's military hardware, while often out-performing the USA equivalent, costs much less to develop and purchase than the USA military's hardware:
Su-27: $30 million per jet
Su-35: $40 - 66 million per jet
F-35: $99 - 250 million per jet, plus an exquisitely-expensive R&D program
And the F-35 is less maneuverable, slower, more prone to issue than the Russian jets (any many other jets), and loses in war drills to old combat fighters.

Comment: No I did not say that.  No matter how comfortable people are around bears, bears can be unpredictable and when one misjudges that and is not prepared for that they put their lives in danger in any bear encounter. Treadwell's 10 year summer living with the Coastal Brown Bears shows as one wildlife biologist stated just how these bears are really tolerant of humans. I know from spending time in Katmai as far back as the 1970's that our discussions on bear behavior was that when the bears were eating salmon that is what they are engaged in 100% since most bears are loners unless they have cubs, so they are into their annual socializing at the salmon streams. But finding a lone brownie or a mother with cubs is a different story and they are more protective and are more wary of humans. I do know from 10 years on Kodiak Island that sharing any area with a large population of bears a lot just increases the odds that you will have a direct encounter with a bear, you think? So be prepared.

Comment: The government must provide regulation, because corporations and the people who run these corporations have shown, time after time, that they are either unwilling or unable to police themselves. We need something like the Securities Exchange Commission that can say to a company such as Enron, "bend over and spread 'em" and make it meaningful.

Remember that in the Enron mess, the accounting firm Arthur Anderson was supposed to be a financial watchdog, but there was a conflict of interest Anderson was providing both auditing services and consulting services to Enron, and was making more on the consulting side (we are talking $20 million). The Enron higher-ups told Anderson that if they wanted to keep the consulting contracts, the auditors had better give a favorable report. So Anderson caved in. And now Arthur Anderson is no more.

Is government oversight perfect? Of course not. It wasn't until Business Week ran a story about accounting problems at Enron that the SEC paid a visit.

Comment: My understanding of the rationale for the Senate was to tamp down the democratic and often unruly deliberative processes of the House and allow calmer voices to prevail. Like the Roman Senate, it was meant to be filled with elders ("senex" = elder) who took their time and thought through issues the House may have given short shrift. Less responsive to popular pressure because of six-year terms, the Senate has used the filibuster to suit its purposes: extending debate rather than cutting it off prematurely because one party or the other is in power. (My understanding of US government may be faulty here, so I welcome input from those who know the subject better.)
I'm also not sure this is a helpful strategy for Democrats, since the Gorsuch nomination, if confirmed, leaves the Court in essentially the same position as it was with Scalia. I'm not sure it's a good strategy to hand Mr. Trump a carte blanche to nominate whomever he wants to replace Ginsburg or Kennedy in future.

The only tip I can recall is :  Females should be careful about wearing scarves so as not to "confuse" communicants that they were wearing the stole of a priest.  "Are they crazy,?" she asked. Comment: I support the NEA (and yes, I support the arts directly with personal donations). It saddens me to read the many negative comments on this thread. Even if you feel you gain nothing from the arts, consider the economic multiplier effect noted in the article. Concerts, exhibits, and other performances funded by the NEA consistently generate local economic activity far exceeding the amount of the grant. Consider also that arts funding represents such a minuscule part of the federal budget that zeroing it out would accomplish next to nothing in terms of national debt (the same goes for Meals on Wheels and other social programs on the block).

How about this: every time Trump goes to Mar-a-Lago for the weekend it costs taxpayers $3 million, so let's ask him to skip the golf course and just stay at the White House a few more weekends. If he does that six times this year, the savings to the taxpayer would equal Alaska's arts funding for the next twenty years!

Comment: TNR and releasing domesticated animals into the wild are two different things, as is managing a feral cat colony. Releasing domesticated animals into the wild is a bad idea, and this animal rescue group should not be advocating for that. Feeding feral cat colonies is also a bad idea in many cases. TNR just insures they aren't reproducing. Very different from feeding the colony or introducing pets into the wild.

Comment: A very well thought out written letter by Linberg. I gave my only child up for adoption when I was nineteen. At that time four decades ago there were hardly any options except to hand her off to Catholic Charities. I do not rue my decision because as a God based program to match infants with potential parents, they did a wonderful job and a wonderful match. I first met my child as a grown up when I was forty two. If other options were to let her live and grow up with her Native roots, then maybe I would have opted for that. On the other hand I wanted the best for her, and she got it. One only thing that concerns me is that I own stock in two Native Corporations, I'm not sure if I can leave them to her since she was adopted by others and not legally my next of kin.  That was always the problem with Natives, our lands taken, so inheritance was always a meager thing to the next generation. It just seems like inheritance issues are never a consideration. This needs to be looked at.

Comment: But you can use them to offset other medical expenses.

The benefits given to union workers now go above and beyond anything that was fought for in the beginning, far exceeding the original goals.
That said, I have no issue with private sector unions. 

Public unions however are a different animal. Spending tax payer dollars, from a position in which they can essentially hold hostage fellow hard working taxpayers that pay their wages and benefits.  This allows them to ask for compensation above what an employee doing the same job in the private sector could expect to receive for the same work.  Most workers in the private sector cannot get their employers to pay for coverage for their families, much less at such a high percentage. 

You could make the case that in turn the private sector should raise wages and benefits, but at that point you raise the spectre of public entities rigging the game against small business.  

This can of worms makes public sector unions a bad idea.

Comment: "So, either make our system fair through proportionality, or prohibit the formation of political parties. I don't care which, but choose one approach."

These are rather extreme opposites.  PR gives more power to parties, taking it away from local MPs.

But back to the initial comment - why not get better voters?  Why are we blaming 'the system' before looking in the mirror?  If voters think (mistakenly) that they're voting for anything other than a local candidate for MP, then surely we are at least part of whatever alleged problem we're trying to fix through ER.

I fully support removing party affiliations from ballots - they don't belong there.  If a voter can't figure out for whom/what they're voting without a 'blue team', 'red team', 'orange team', 'green team', etc. cliff note, that voter is not doing their civic duty.

If we want a 'better' parliament, all we have to do is elect better parliamentarians!

Comment: Mitchell;  perhaps I can help. The lands that might be taken into trust need to be fee lands owned by tribes. A little fee land has been conveyed to tribes by ANCs. Some other tribes own fee lands that used to be their reservations before ANCSA; those five tribes chose to retain former reservation lands in fee instead of participating fully in the Settlement. They kept their lands but received no money or shares. 
There is no mandate for ANCs to convey land to tribes. There are around 6 million acres now owned by tribes that might qualify. That would be 1.6 of the state IF all of it were successfully petitioned. Alaska is about 375 million acres. Total ANCSA lands are about 44 million acres; Village Corps own about 22 million of those. The only way that 10% of the state would go into trust would be if ALL the ANCSA land was conveyed to tribes AND all of it was accepted into trust. Highly unlikely to happen and it would take decades to complete all the petitions.

The ideas stand on their own.  Putting a personal identification serves only to facilitate pigeon-holing without serious thought.

Comment: That's the silliest thing I've ever read. Strikes and mass action are solutions against EMPLOYER abuses - not government abuses - it only overlaps in those cases where the employer is the government - and even then having MPs in parliament doesn't change their need since it's the civil service, not parliament, that does the employing.

Strikes are disruptive of course, they are meant to be, and there is a simple bit of maths you can do. Instead of wailing about what it costs the country when some union goes on strike - do the math. That cost - the total combined cost to the ENTIRE economy that their strike imposed, is the actual value of their labour TO the economy.
Now subtract their actual wages from that cost - and if the difference is too large, you understand two things (1) why strikes are needed and (2) just how severe the theft of capitalism truly is.

Comment: This electoral reform idea was entirely about pushing power from Right to Left.  If it had passed, it would have made it immensely harder for the CPC to get elected with a majority in future.  In the past the CPC benefited from left vote being split between the Libs, NDP, Greens and Bloc.  But if you give all these parties larger pieces of the parliamentary pie, the easy math is the CPC would win substantially fewer seats even if they win plurality.

The reason the Libs ditched it is: they do not wan minority government power, they want majority power.  Just as the CPC would lose seats with proportional voting, the LIbs would also lose some to the NDP and Greens, increasing the risk they would only win only a minority of seats in any given election.

I think it is a good thing that we stick with the existing system.  Canada is better off with majority governments - whether Conservative or Liberal. Better than handing king maker power to Liz May or Peter Julien etc.

Hirst vs. Whatcom is a ploy to drive people into cities and control their resources. It's not about conservation.

Comment: @Con:  You're getting your Fox New talking points confused.   The votes in the Electoral College go by state - not county.   The winner of the most votes in each STATE receives ALL of the electoral votes allocated to that state (the votes each state has in the EC are equivalent to that state's number of reps in both houses of Congress) with the exception of Nebraska and Maine - which allow their state's electoral votes to be divided depending on which candidate receives the most votes in each CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT - not county.   Trump won the election with a minority of the popular votes cast across the USA.  He can't get over that FACT.

Comment: Most of the calls we get, involve open concept office issues. It is unfortunate that sound dampening, and/or sound masking  is not often considered in the original design, of the open office space. On paper, the open office concept is a great idea, unfortunately acoustic issues are not evident on paper. Quite a few of our customers did not think, that after they converted their office space to an open concept office, it would be so loud and noisy.

I think we can all agree that hard, flat, reflective, parallel surfaces, create poor room acoustics for any open office.

Acoustic desk partitions can help, but nominally. Better acoustic ceiling tiles will help. Acoustic panels installed on the walls and ceiling can dampen the noise by 35% to 45%.

After the room is quieter, you may still struggle with privacy issues, Sound masking can help with this.

www.TheQuietRoom.ca

Comment: PERA retirees faced the Colorado Supreme Court in 2014 via Justus vs. State of Colorado. After both sides argued their case, the justices asked some questions.  One justice asked the attorney representing the Colorado AG regarding the difference between the fixed 3.5% annual raise (aka COLA) for retirees and the core PERA benefit itself, since both were in statute.  The attorney stated that the AG office considered neither the COLA nor the PERA benefit itself to be contractual, but the base benefit was afforded more legal scrutiny.  Therefore, the inference was that the COLA was strictly a gratuity, but the base benefit was a non-contractual promise which would need strong compelling reasons to alter.  It will take another round through the courts to determine whether the base benefit is a contractual obligation.  The vast majority of PERA members and retirees are in the dark regarding this matter, and the PERA board and management would like to keep it that way.

Comment: EGI has been a UO poster child for decades.  Unfortunately, EGI shows where UO and business diverge, i.e. in a sense in where profit lies.  EGI has always addressed a very small specialized market with limited opportunity to expand.  In my opinion, they made a big mistake in going public.  Now they have to answer to shareholders and divulge prior private financial information.  The emperor's clothes have been stripped off so to speak.  With losses revealed and likely survival based on government grants, we may be able to learn how flimsy UO endeavors are.  They may be able to survive if they strip away the big ticket salaries, but with a limited market, big time success is hard to imagine (unless they actually find useful cost effective diagnostic applications which are not already trumped by alternative technologies).  Based on the last several years losses, it looks like their investors are going to lose their shirts.  I wonder if their looking forward IPO disclosures were honest.

Comment: A couple of years ago I investigated buying a 1/4 acre plot and putting a tiny home on it (no wheels, a real foundation).

I was informed and surprised to find out that a lot of towns (big and small) have a minimum sq footage requirement that is MUCH larger than most tiny homes.   In other words, yes you can build / place a tiny home in our town ... as long as it's not "tiny."

I suggest people do their homework with city govt. officials BEFORE you even start planning to build or buy (pre-fabricated and shipped) a tiny home in a lot of Colorado's cities and even small towns.

Comment: In the first opera of the New Year, the first scene shocked the audience. The character Maltrumpio, mere weeks before his coronation, was about to sing 'presso conferencia', a moment of unparalleled pride. But he pulled a Mariah. Stunning, uncomfortable silence. Kelliania and Melankia, his most trusted females, held 'carta delle cue' to assist him with his impromptu remarks, but there was nothing. His eyes darted about, lost. It was like the Perverdi opera "Usignolo" (the Nightengale) performance in 1598, when the proud tenor Adicio was about to sing his aria, bird excrement fell on his gorgeous hair. The shame and shock ended his career, dispelling the silly myth. But in our opera, the curtain fell on Maltrumpio. The audience could only guess at the tweetilos soon to come.

What zero tolerance policy?  What do those words mean?  It appears to mean a priest is stood down from his duties when an accusation is made and until some determination is made as to the charges.  At least it means that in the U.S. and some other countries when it comes to diocesan priests.  Have no idea what it means outside of Europe, N. Amer., and Australia.   Religious order priests or brothers or sisters - a mystery.

It does not mean priests are removed from the priesthood if found guilty, because something like 40% of cases that go to the CDF are not removed from the priesthood.  It certainly does not mean that bishops complicit in the coverup of child sex abuse are stood down.  It certainly does not mean that bishops are to inform the police - except where required to by law.  And, it doesn't mean anything about how the victim is treated, about justice for the victim.

Comment: "Renting is an absolutely viable alternative to owning as long as you're able to take your savings from not paying property taxes and home maintenance and invest it. "  Rob, you do realize that the landlord pays these costs out of of the rent that he collects from the tenants. 

Owning is normally cheaper than renting over time, as rent always escalates, while mortgage payments are typically quite flat (subject to interest rate variations).  And rent should cover the all the landlords costs + a return on his investment - ie the renter is paying for use of the landlord's capital.   The challenge that first time home buyers face is coming up with initial downpayment to get into the market.  In a world where started homes cost $1m and rents are high, it is not easy for 25-30 year olds to come up with the $50-$100K of after tax capital required.

Comment: All is not gloom and doom in Alberta.

Two anecdotes from my rural central Alberta neighbourhood:

One of the good ol' boys at the local watering hole owns an oil services company. Just last week he borrowed $400K to buy a new service rig. He has work for the new rig in the Provost area that will create 3 jobs. About 170 exploration rigs are currently operating in Alberta (double the number of operating rigs at this time last year). Where the exploration rigs go the service rigs soon follow.

A young woman just down the road from my place is raising goats. Initially she was selling the milk to a cheese manufacturer for feta and some milk went to the lactose intolerant market. She started selling the unwanted male kids and the old nannies into the halal meat market. That has turned out to be very profitable for her. This smart young woman has created 2 new jobs.

Never count out the resiliency of the Alberta entrepreneur.

Comment: The early Church found it's way because those first Christians had the passion that flowed from their own intimate experience of Christ. Without that passion, they never would have had the staying power to grow the movement.

The question for this generation is how do we sustain a church that has become unwieldy and, in some ways, detached from the passion of the first disciples. Some are looking for their passion in forms and traditions while others are seeking to recapture the original revolutionary spirit of the early Church. I'm skeptical that those two paths will ever merge.

Pope Francis seems convicted that the salvation of the Church lies in communion with the poor and that anything that gets in the way of that can be jettisoned. I think he's right. And the good news is that none of us needs to wait for somebody else, least of all the hierarchy, to take the lead.

Comment: A lot of the forms of chemicals in supplements are not the chemical forms found in food that humans eat.   For example, you can buy an excellent b-vitamin supplement with the forms your body can use, and it will likely run around $25 per month.   Or, you can use the el cheapo stuff that is not 'bio-identical', it will run about $10 - $15 per month.  A lot of people's bodies won't be able to absorb or metabolize the cheap stuff though, and it can cause problems.

While I much prefer to get my nutrients from food and think that's best for most of us, there are people whose lives and health can be enhanced (and some serious medical conditions managed) by using a high-quality bio-identical supplement in the amounts needed.

Comment: Actually, neither risk nor expected reward drive cost.
.
Imaginings of expected reward (i.e., future price), and the relative volatility of that expected future price (a measure of risk), may drive future supply.
.
Cost is the sum of the price of inputs, which is itself a function of demand in the market for those inputs at the time they are purchased.
.
Were this not so, there would be no market for futures options in, for example, the grain, copper, iron, or oil markets (or much of anything else, either) to hedge against the risk of future volatility in the prices of those goods.

Comment: I get your point, On-Line, but it's not always the name that screams "sugar."  Not any more.  Once upon an era, my parents bought the kids Sugar Frosted Flakes and Sugar Pops (which featured TV western star Guy Madison on the front of the box. Wild Bill was a favourite of mine.  Anyway...) 

In the early 1980s, the word "sugar" was dropped.  "Frosted" was kept on the flakes, the "pops" became plain old "corn pops."  Did Kelloggs "hold the sugar"? It did not. Later, Kelloggs developed the mini-wheat line--small shredded-wheat sized cereal. One of the entries: "Frosted."  

What screams at me every time I hit the cereal aisle is the SHELF SPACE devoted to foods sold basically for sugar content (Count Chocula, et al.) compared to non-sugar, or, at least, moderately-sweetened cereals. No secret what sells best.

Comment: Dealing with no-cost banks like PC Fin or Tangerine is a pain.  No branches, no personal interaction and only call-centre staff to help out.  Setting up a PC Fin account has been a time sucking exercise in futility. Tangerine set up my account, but refused my request for a simple overdraft, despite my 800+ credit score, paid off mortgage and zero debt. They also can't or won't explain why. At least my real bank provided all the services I need, and I negotiated free banking with all the other products I hold.

The author has a long history of hating on Banks, but with PC Fin being absorbed back into CIBC, and Tangerine just BNS lite, my options are a rag-tag association of credit unions that can't offer all the services I need? 

Perhaps free banking works for some, but once your financial life has a bit of complexity, you need a real bank to work with. 

As for mortgage rate negotiations, Carrick's logic applies to all banks, not just the Big 5.

Comment: Good article. I teach CCD & I use the "telephone wire and pole" image to describe how we can use prayer throughout our day in order to stay close to God. Children (and adults) get it immediately.

The line sags as our "approaches" to God get farther and farther apart.  There's tension, sadness, loneliness, or  worse the farther these approaches get closer.

Catholics have a marvelous history of various forms and types of prayer.

The morning offering, immediately upon awakening... Father I want to give you my whole day, all my works, joys and struggles. Help me. 

The Angelus (or in Eastertide, the Regina Coeli) at noon...1 minute prayer easy to memorize.

The Rosary which can be done at one time or spread across the day, like our Pope does.  He says I think three parts per day (3 whole sets of mysteries). 

A short examination (1 minute):  Thank you for...I'm sorry for....Help me more on x, y, z tomorrow.

5 minutes of reading the NT each day like the Pope recommends.

Aspirations too

Comment: Technically, yes, man is part of Nature. We are an evolved biological species that Linnaeus placed in the Animal Kingdom. There the comparison stops. While we evolved with the ability to rationalize and reason, we have [ab]used that ability to connive, cajole, lie, cheat, and steal our way to the top – at the expense of not only others of our species, but all other species as well. Comment: Mahalo, Civil Beat, for your passionate, principled endorsement of sanctuary status for our beloved if beleaguered state. And congrats, too, on what appears to be growing readership by Trump supporters. Listening to them is something many of us failed to do earlier, and their comments are instructive. 

Rail, homelessness, overdevelopment, prison-packing and more: These local problems all deserve our attention. We have a right to participate in their solutions, and there is ample opportunity to do so. 

Sanctuary status is altogether different. It is a definitional issue, declaring and confirming who we are as a people in the face of a would-be despot who demands that we be otherwise. As burdensome as it could be, adopting it is necessary. If we are people of aloha, we must live that aloha beyond bumper stickers. If we are people of aloha, we cannot shirk the responsibility invoked in our state motto. where righteousness, not complacency or fear, is job No 1.

Comment: So half of us pay a hefty state income tax (because the level of tax needed to balance the budget would have to be very, very high), so that the State can essentially give it away to everyone?    It makes no sense.   And therein lies the flaw in the above argument.   The PF was not created to be be able to fund individual dividends for people who simply lived here a year.   It was a neat idea when we had more revenue than we needed to fund operations and sensible capital improvements.    The Fund's purpose was to benefit all Alaskans including future generations.    An investment model that generates revenue to fund state services benefits all Alaskans present and future by reducing the income and sales tax burdens on ALL Alaskans, present and future.    It's time to face reality: with the reduction of production levels and oil prices, there isn't enough revenue to give away.    Unfortunately It's time for the PF earnings to be utilized in the manner for which they were intended.

Comment: The key to the book of Revelation and any "End Times" prophesy is not found in Revelation but in the book of Daniel and the "7-year peace treaty" Israel signs with "many."
-
If we assume - hope - that this "peace treaty" might be signed sometime in the next 10 years (many, including Israel, are hoping "a whole lot sooner," but let's go with the 10 years), then that means the treaty could be signed on any day in the next 3,650 days......so one's odds of correctly picking the correct date is far, far, far more likely than winning any lottery. 
-
But randomly picking first Sept 23, 2017, then Oct. 15, 2017, and now Nov. 19, 2017 is picking 3 dates out of 3,650.....and the odds aren't that good since it is highly more likely that that date is as wrong as the first two.
-
But the question is: Was Sept. 23, 2017 a "sign" that something would happen "on" 9/23/2017 or "after" 9/23/2017? To those who think it "foreshadows" events that will "soon" come, for them, the jury is still out.

Comment: Relax everybody. The total federal debt is forecast to stay about the same as the proportion of GDP. Future generations will not be worse off just because the federal debt on the books will be bigger. They are not going to pay it off, just like we are not paying off the debt from the generations before us. However, the future generations WILL be worse off if we don't maintain the country infrastructure and the health and education systems. Those are the real assets that matter in people's lives. If we pay off the federal debt ten times over and not build anything and not maintain what we have, the future generations will have a large number in the federal treasury account, but nothing to show for it.
We should worry about the private debt of Canadians. That's our problem, not the debt of the federal government.

Comment: Huh??? This is so innacurate and misleading.... let's explain the reality. They CAN'T ASK FOR PUNITIVE damages, per-se, as their complaint doesn't allege any direct harm on behalf of the defendant. Last time I checked, and for the last several hundred years of common-law application, that was still a prerequisite element to any type of puntitive entitlement. The fact is, compensatory damages are much more appealing, as they are not taxable like punitive damages. More importantly, in Colorado, any type of "injury" including an emotional injury can be levied against the liable party.
 To say that "Not seeking punitive damages, so the likelihood of a big payday is slim. Compensatory damages would be medical expenses and maybe lost wages if she missed any work. If she suffered permanent damage there could be damages for the disability" is entirely inaccurate, as the majority of the damages, comprising a large payday being sought, would fall in to the category of emotional injury.

Comment: I stand by my earlier comment. The problem is oversupply of universities in Ontario. Period. Ontario has more than 20 universities and another 20+ community colleges. It is a very expensive proposition to run a university or college, and the cost is borne mostly through provincial government spending, not student tuitions.  Check out the facts.  Yes, I've been to OUIT.  It has ONE Tier 1 Canada Research Chair.  A medium-sized university like McMaster has over 30.  There is already a network of nuclear engineering studies between Western, McMaster and Waterloo. Windsor has an established program in automotive engineering. There was already an oversupply of education faculties in the province when OUIT's was established.  From Oshawa's perspective, it seems great to have a local university with its infrastructure and 1300+ well-paying faculty and admin. jobs, but from a provincial, fiscal perspective, the redundancy is very expensive.

Comment: Nope, it was part of the deal I agreed do.  My starting pay was $90/mo in 1967.  The GI Bill benefits are "deferred compensation."  And, unlike other mortgages, a VA loan, which can be for 100% of the home's value, can't be walked away from and discharged in a bankruptcy.  If you default on a VA loan and the government has to pay for a loss, that loss becomes a liability owed by you to the federal government, and until it's paid, you won't get another mortgage from VA, FHA, Fannie Mae, or Freddie Mac.  And that's why the default rate is low on VA loans for 100%.  You can't default on them and get away with it.

You want free college, free housing, free food and clothing, free job skills training, and a livable wage?  It's all available to you now.  See your local recruiter and serve your country, and you can get all of that.

Oh, you expected it for nothing?  More young men died on the streets of Chicago than In Iraq and Afghanistan.  You're safer in a combat zone.

Comment: Reread the study...a VERY small and very biased sample (32,800 voters that was not representative) was used, found 339 self-identified non-citizens (about 1%) and 39 of the 339 said they voted (about 1/5 of 1%). The authors extrapolated that number to the entire country without considering the accuracy of their data - for example, they had information from 2008, 2010 and 2012, and 20 respondents changed their answers on the "citizenship question" for each survey. The original authors didn't even notice this.

The study used the data from the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, a non-partisan research group - they have criticized the methods used by the authors (including Richman - one 'h') and have demanded they withdraw the study...which doesn't matter because the authors can't get the study published in a peer-reviewed journal because of its amateurish methods...

So, you're gonna hang your hat on that? Read anything by Larry Sabato at U of Virginia that samples millions...

Comment: Not including F series of funds is a mistake.  Front end or A series funds are only sold through financial advisors, who typically take 1% of the management fee as a commission.  If you buy an ETF through one of these advisors, they will change you a 1% (or higher) account fee.  So the only way to compare ETFs and mutual funds is to use funds without embedded commission, which is the F series.  So Gordon Pape crunched the numbers incorrectly.

Most active mutual funds in Canada charge around 1% pre-tax for fees.  The average active ETF is around 0.65%.  Not that much of a difference.  Passive is a different story and tends to be less expensive.  In recent years, passive has worked well.  Since the financial crisis, almost everything has gone up and market cap weighted indexes favour big stocks, so true active management has been difficult.  That will change.  There is a lot of risk in holding everything during a bear market.

Comment: We were holding my mother's 90th birthday celebration a couple of yeas ago & wanted to have it a her favourite restaurant in Montreal.  Approximately 35 guests, mostly from out of town.  The menu selection was agreed upon - appetizers & dinner cost approximately $150 - $175 per person + taxes & gratuities - plus champagne, wine & liquor (open bar) - a considerable amount.  We were willing to pay for dessert - no problem, but wanted a special Tiffany cake that could accommodate the families' allergies, which their desserts could not.  In addition, this was a professional cake, made by one of the top patisseries in Montreal.  The reason for Tiffany - my mother was from New York - it was one of her favourite stores - & her special presents from her grandchildren were coming from Tiffany's Canada.  The response from the establishment - no. 

We declined.  Fortunately our home is large enough that we were able to rent a tent for the backyard and cater the event. We have not gone back.

Comment: "exactly who do we want? From Where? Why? As long was the Canadian people are given the opportunity to decide..."

Exactly.

The notion that the people actually living in a country get to decide who can join them, not their rulers,  seems a difficult concept to some.

We are still living with the consequences of the times when the land belonged to rulers, and they got it by conquest, or marriage alliances, or bartering it with other rulers, and the people just came with it like livestock.

"Nationalism" came along with democracy, i.e. the revolutionary notion that a country belonged to its people, not its rulers, and they alone had the right to decide how it should be run, and who they would invite to join them.

Now we seem to have gone back full circle, with our rulers feeling they alone should decide, and the people should have no say.

Comment: Here's the truth:

*  Human rights tribunals are bound by the Charter.
*  Rules of evidence apply.
*  More respondents than applicants appear with legal representation.
*  There is no 100% conviction rate - tribunals dismiss overwhelming more cases than they grant.
*  In fact, there are no convictions; human rights cases are civil law, not criminal.
*  In the few cases that applicants win, the tribunal orders the respondent to pay them damages; there are no fines, there is no jail.

Why you emphasize that you are white is known only to you.

Comment: Limiting terms would help; however,  the process that created this dysfunction would remain and the net gain might be minimal. Here are some suggestions:  First, place the Legislature under the State Open Meeting Statute.  Second, take away the defacto veto power granted to individual legislators who can simply refuse to hear bills before various committees. Third, either stop introducing legislation or resolve every bill by defeating it, passing it, combining it with similar legislation, or having it withdrawn by the sponsor.  Forth, elect the State Attorney General. Fifth, require all meetings with lobbyists to be placed on the public record and finally diminish the ability of the Governor to so strongly influence the redistricting process. Sixth, apportion the  State Senate by geographic area instead of by population.  And finally, limit contributions so that only registered voters can contribute to elected officials who by Constitution are authorized to represent them.

Comment: The only thing medicine would solve today in Juneau, is to fly the whole legislature to Mt. Pavlov, and toss em in the Volcano. Bill Walker had a little '64 experience. "In 1964 the eminent psychologist H. J. Eysenck reviewed Pavlov's "Lectures on Conditioned Reflexes" for the British Medical Journal: Volume I – "Twenty-five Years of Objective Study of the Higher Nervous Activity of Animals", Volume II – "Conditioned Reflexes and Psychiatry".

The Pavlov Institute of Physiology of the Russian Academy of Sciences was founded by Pavlov in 1925 and named after him following his death.Pavlov was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1904. He was elected a Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in 1907 and was awarded the Royal Society's Copley Medal in 1914. He became a foreign member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1907. Pavlov's dog, the Pavlovian session and Pavlov's typology are named in his honour.

Comment: I have never had a need to put together a complete CV and there is not nearly enough room in the limited space allowed here. But I will tell you I have been at this for nearly 50 years with my wildlife research starting when I was in high school. I used to go to the UC Berkeley campus to look over scientific publications in the Life Sciences Library.  My first big accomplishment was in my 20's. I helped set up a successful Peregrine Falcon captive breeding facility in CA.  They were endangered at the time with only 5 nest sites known in CA. Anyone can find my articles on the internet. Just look up my name with the words eagles, turbines or wind energy.

Comment: From my State of the County address last month:

When the legislature passed PERS reform in 2013, our financial, legal and Human Resources staff recommended to the Board that we set aside the projected savings in a reserve account because of the potential for those reforms to be overturned in the courts. In addition, that same staff had bonded some of our PERS liability when interest rates were low and nearly fully funded our liability. 

This higher level of funding directly impacts the rate that Lane County is charged to cover PERS expenses for our employees. While other public employers in Oregon, with less than 80 percent of their PERS liability funded, saw their rates raise by as much as 6 percentage points in FY 15- 16, Lane County experienced an increase of just 1.8 percentage points for the same time period. If we had experienced a 6 percentage point increase, it would have cost Lane County an additional $3.3 million dollars annually.

You have yet to establish connection between Moore's record and her credibility as a writer or viability of her political views.  All you've established is you disagree with her.  Blaming it on her past is a cheap shot.  I realize it's much easier than challenging her arguments with facts and/or logic, but in lieu of evidence to the contrary she's REHABILITATED.  Someone even hired her (gasp)!

The Most Noble Messenger (Saala Allahu alayhi wa Ah'liihi wa Salaam) said, "Accept the truth, even from your bitter enemy.  Reject a lie, even from your nearest kinsman."  That's reasonable.  For you to argue that a previous conviction taints every word that flows from her pen isn't.

Comment: This is a strong, clear Op-Ed. I wish the R-G editorial board would officially come out in favor of the Clean Energy Jobs Bill too. It's not perfect, but it's worlds better than what's being pursued in most of the other states. Everyone reading this should call-write-email his/her state reps in favor of it. 

My only reservation concerns the extent to which the Bill would preserve/honor the "Oregon constitutional requirement that revenue generated from vehicle fuel must go to roads." 

Monies generated from carbon fees SHOULD go into encouraging and constructing alternatives to roads. cars, and trucks. It would be self-defeating to use the market to discourage carbon fuel use while also encouraging carbon-powered vehicle use. 

At the very least, greater provision should be made for rewarding buyers, users, and builders of electric powered vehicles.

Comment: "Fair, in this sense, means equal."

Fair means corresponding to your ability, not equal. This is the same reason why elementary school and collegiate athletes do not compete against each other at sporting events.

"Works for me." No, it really doesn't. Implementing a flat tax model based on what the lowest-income citizens' ability to pay would reduce individual income taxes to nearly zero. This would eliminate almost half our federal tax revenue, and of course we are already operating at a deficit of $400+ billion per year. 

Let me guess: you want to cut spending to match that reduced revenue level, right? The problem with that is that paying our current obligations - Social Security to those who have already paid into it and service on the national debt for revenues already spent - would consume nearly all of it. We would have almost nothing left for defense, health, veteran's services, transportation, or anything else. That wouldn't work for you at all, even if you think it would.

Comment: The income qualification is not spelled out in the bill.  The bill uses language about "eligible recipients" so that the Executive Office on Aging will be able to define the kupuna's eligibility once the bill becomes law.  

 Also, the bill does state that the family caregiver must be employed at least 30 hours per week in his or her own job.  This bill is not seeking to address  all family caregivers nor all senior citizens.  It is addressing a relatively small population: 1) seniors who meet the limited-income criteria to be defined by the Executive Office on Aging AND 2) who are being cared for by family members who already hold down an outside job at least 30 hours per week.  The intent is to help both the kupuna in need of care and the family member who is burning himself/herself out because they are providing care on top of doing their own paid job.  The intent is actually to save money for the taxpayers by helping kupuna BEFORE they need to turn to Medicaid.  Hope this helps.

Comment: Unfortunately, the study is very flawed.  For instance, there are several models of 7-day supply/demand balances.  In one, there is no drop in demand on Saturday and Sunday; in another, there is such a drop in three days out of seven.  In all, the morning peak in demand is often higher than the late afternoon peak, something rarely seen in South Africa.  They hope to balance things out with combined cycle gas turbines [CCGT] by 2020, but it is nearly 2018 and there is no sign of any gas, let alone any CCGT stations. Although the authors are German, they take no account of the German experience, which is having to build 19 new coal-fired power stations to balance their grid even though they have extensive interconnections to the rest of Europe.  We have no such level of connectedness. And Germany nearly lost control last winter when there was no wind for two weeks, and only great efforts by their neighbours saved them.  Beware the Germans bearing gifts!

Comment: Your animosity is understandable. However, the negative consequences of the hostile act you propose would far outweigh any transient satisfaction you'd get from doing it. Chrystia Freeland is to be commended for doing so as she attempts to salvage NAFTA and save Trump from his own worst impulses.

As we watch in disbelief while Trump incompetently "tweaks" the Free Trade Agreement, it becomes clear that he has little understanding of what words (and promises) mean, and even less understanding of the fundamentals of reciprocal trade. He wants to have his cake and eat it. If he can't reconstruct NAFTA to his own advantage, he'll just pout and walk away from it, not realizing (or not caring) that he has shot himself in the foot to please his small power base. "Buy American" only, and it's bye-bye America. If that happens, then you'll get lasting satisfaction -- and problems of your own.

Comment: Here is what happened.  Due to the failure of the Articles of Confederation a Constitutional Convention convened in Annapolis, MD in 1786 and then reconvened in Philadelphia, PA in 1787.  The Constitution was vehemently argued over from May - September 1787 and the compromise document was submitted to the People and their elected representatives in each State for ratification.  The ratification process was no slam dunk for the supporters of the Constitution, it almost failed.  Supporters of the Constitution were known as Federalists, non-supporters as Anti-Federalists.  Thanks to the anti-Federalists we had the first 10 amendments to the Constitution known as the Bill of Rights in 1791.  But, those first amendments actually started out as 12.  One of those 12 became part of the Constitution on 5 May 1992, as the 27th Amendment and believe it or not, one amendment is still pending before the states.
